newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW - Netscape lands big orders.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Netscape lands big orders.

text.p: Netscape Communications Corp has secured critical orders from more than 100 large customers since October, representing more than one million individual users, a senior executive said Wednesday.

Mike Homer, Netscape's senior vice president of marketing, said the customer design "wins," or orders, involve companies that have chosen its upcoming Communicator product and its SuiteSpot server products for either corporate messaging or business critical applications.
A win is Netscape's term for a sale to a customer who deploys the product to more than 500 individual users, or seats.
Separately, he said Netscape's Communicator Internet software will be released within 30 days.

"The imperative is to ship the product as quickly as we possibly can. It has to be out right away," Homer told Reuters in an interview late Wednesday. "We have a whole bunch (of customers) that are queued up until we ship the product."

Homer declined to say how many orders or customers had said they would commit once the product ships, however, and he said the 100 customers were a particular subset of total new business in the period. He declined to give total figures.
He also would not say whether the release of Communicator, now in a public beta test period, would be made prior to the company's developers conference in San Jose on June 11-12.
But he asserted its release will give Netscape a four- to five-month jump over the next release of rival Microsoft Corp.'s upcoming Internet Explorer 4.0 version.
"Microsoft hasn't even gone into public beta yet," he said. Netscape posted a Communicator preview in December.

Brad Chase, vice president of Microsoft's applications and Internet clients group, said Wednesday the next version of Microsoft's browser would be available during the summer, but declined to give a specific time frame until feedback from an upcoming beta testing period can be evaluated.
"Right now, summer is what we believe we'll make," he told Reuters in an interview.
Previously, Netscape has said the final shipping version of its Netscape Communicator will be available by the end of the second quarter on June 30.

Internet Explorer will be free and shipped with Microsoft operating systems, while Netscape Communicator, which includes an array of added capabilities, will have a retail price of $59 and a professional edition, with more features, for $79.

Chrysler Corp, which is using Netscape products to build a dealer network, Prudential Healthcare, Scotia Capital Markets and Bay Networks are among the companies included by Netscape in its list of 100 critical customer wins.
Netscape said a more detailed list would be released on Thursday morning, with further descriptions of how customers are deploying its software in a variety of settings.

The U.S. Defense Logistics Agency, for example, has agreed to use the software to deploy applications on both its Intranet -- an internal network using Internet technology -- and Extranets, which run between different parties' networks.

Many of the customer design wins involve electronic mail systems, and Homer said this alone compares favourably with an International Data Corp industry forecast of 8.5 million e-mail seats to be sold in 1997.

Shares of Netscape have been volatile in the last week, tumbling roughly 15 percent last Friday after an analyst downgraded the stock to a "short-term avoid" and investors were rattled by fresh worries over a company statement in a regular federal filing that its historical growth rates will slow.

But several analysts said the sell-off was overdone, noting Netscape has provided cautious comments about its future financial performance in prior filings and the company is about to enter a strong phase of its new product cycle.
(sam.perry@reuters.com, in Palo Alto, +1 415 846 5400)
